utterances: Organic food, I won't buy it right now.
It's just too expensive.
That's how Krause ended up at the Shoppers.
And Krause says that she isn't the only person she knows who feels this way.
She recalls a conversation that she had the previous weekend when she and a girlfriend were getting ready for a small vacation.
We were packing out to go away for the weekend, and my one friend had her Whole Foods bags full of clothes.
And I said, it's good to know you get another use out of the bags or whatever.
And she said yeah, this is the last set.
She said we won't be buying these bags anymore.
And I said, what do you mean?
And she said, can't shop there anymore.
Krause says she didn't push further.
She knew exactly what her friend meant.
Alix Spiegel, NPR News, Washington.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Susan Stamberg.
Steve Inskeep is on assignment.
Dennis is a tropical storm now, blasting heavy rains, tornadoes, but it was a 120-mile-an-hour hurricane when it came ashore yesterday just east of Pensacola, Florida.
Last evening, local residents started to survey the damage.
NPR's Ari Shapiro reports there was some relief in Pensacola that Dennis hadn't been quite as awful as they'd expected.
Yesterday morning words like record-setting and historic were all over the airwaves.
As a Category 4 hurricane, Dennis looked destine to become the strongest storm ever to hit the Gulf Coast of the United States, but then just before coming ashore, Dennis weakened to Category 3.
And by the time Escambia County Sheriff Ron McNesby spoke at a press conference in Pensacola yesterday evening, it was clear that many people had been very lucky.
Things are really, really good here.
So be patient with the lights.
Be patient with the electricity.
You need to say a little prayer tonight because the good Lord took care of us.
No question about that.
One of the reasons the storm seemed so mild was that just 10 months ago Hurricane Ivan came ashore at the same place and flattened whole neighborhoods.
Dennis knocked down power lines and trees, but after it had passed, one official after another reiterated that it had been nowhere near as bad as people expected.
Still, Escambia County administrator George Touart pointed out that it was a major storm.
Tom Dwyer is director of merchandising for Borders.
He says not only are readers interested in best-seller lists, so are authors.
It is uncanny as you look.
You sense a great deal of pleasure in your being alive.
He who is so full of animation a few moments ago now dies eternally inanimate.
You are alive.
A future is still yours.
Lynette says other Marines have reproduced her brother's poem and carry it in their pockets.
For NPR News, I'm Simone Orendain in Charlotte.
From NPR News this is All Things Considered.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Melissa Block.
Republican presidential candidate John McCain and his running mate, Sarah Palin, campaigned together again today.
The pair took the stage in Lebanon, Ohio, just as President Bush was making his announcement that 8,000 troops will be pulled out of Iraq by February.
McCain and Palin both gave upbeat assessments of the situation in Iraq.
NPR's Don Gonyea is traveling with the McCain campaign.
He joins us from a rally in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
And, Don, how upbeat are they?
They are very upbeat about Iraq.
And it is a continuation of the message that we've been seeing from Senator McCain for some time now.
But Governor Palin has jumped right in on that.
She has been using a particular construct when she describes the status of the war in Iraq as saying victory is within sight.
Now she has also become the person in this ticket who has really been going after Barack Obama.
And what about John McCain's tone?
You know, he took the stage almost at the exact same time President Bush was giving his address at the National Defense University.
Senator McCain was on the street in Lebanon, Ohio, in front of an old double-decker balcony of an old hotel.
And he did not specifically address what President Bush had been talking about.
He too went after Barack Obama, basically questioning his judgment.
Here's Senator McCain.
Senator Obama has refused to acknowledge that he was wrong about the surge.
He said it wouldn't succeed.
Thanks to General David Petraeus and these brave young Americans, we are winning in Iraq.
We will come home with honor.
Again, the message is we are winning in Iraq.
And that is a message that is very popular, at least among these crowds that are turning out to see Senator McCain and Governor Palin.
At the same time, Don, today Barack Obama said, look, this is not enough troops, not enough resources, not enough urgency, talking about this planned withdrawal.
Were there any specifics coming from John McCain and Sarah Palin about their own potential timetable for troop withdrawal?
No, Here's what we get.
We get criticism of Senator Obama, we get predictions of victory, and we get general praise for President Bush, but no specifics.
One last thing, Don.
I gather that Sarah Palin has been repeating again her line that she opposed the so-called bridge to nowhere in Alaska, that ""Thanks, but no thanks"" line.
Any change in the rhetoric at all?
No, I mean there have been many reports in recent days that that statement is misleading at very best and could be seen as just being flat out wrong.

But the position of the McCain campaign, the approach she is taking, is that this is what she has to say about the bridge to nowhere, and she is going to keep saying it regardless of what kind of evidence arises elsewhere.
And again, her basic position is that she opposed the bridge to nowhere, that she killed it.
But we know that she supported the bridge to nowhere and did not oppose it until the federal government said that the 223-million-dollar earmark could not be used on that bridge.
The state of the Alaska did still get that 223 million dollars, but it could use them on other transportation projects.
Only then did she oppose it.
OK.
NPR's Don Gonyea traveling with the McCain campaign at a rally in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
Don, thanks very much.
All right.
Thank you.
My Pleasure.
The FBI and police on the Caribbean island of Trinidad recently joined forces in the arrest of four men suspected of plotting to attack New York's JFK Airport.
It may seem an unlikely alliance, but it's the second time in as many years that the FBI and Trinidad police have worked together on a case.
What's less known is that the bureau also helped Trinidad police break up a kidnapping ring that had terrorized the island.
NPR's Dina Temple-Raston has that story.
Port of Spain used to be known for Calypso music, steel drums, and wild parties during Carnival.
Then it became a boom town.
As the price of natural gas skyrocketed, the island has prospered.
But the newfound riches have also created a raft of problems.
The economic gulf between Indians, who tend to be the merchant class, and blacks has widened.
Crime is endemic.
Gangs rule the slums and, for a time, kidnapping, which tended to target Indians, became an easy way to make a fast buck.
I ran inside to answer the phone.
Debbie Ali became one of those kidnapping victims.
I picked up the phone.
I had my keys in my hand.
And I was just moving to hit the button for the garage door to close, and just as I turned around to hit the button, these two men came in - masked.
Debbie Ali lives about an hour outside of Port of Spain, in an upper middle class subdivision.
It is a neighborhood of two story stucco houses, two car garages, and manicured lawns.
It looks like a suburb of Houston instead of a suburb of Port of Spain.
Debbie Ali stands just five feet tall and weighs about 80 pounds.
She knew she was a prime target for kidnapping.
But when the masked men appeared in her garage, one armed with a machete and another with a gun, she was too stunned to move.
Your reaction is not - snap - to run inside and shut the door or whatever.
You just freeze, and that is sheer shock and sheer terror.
And you literally go cold.
I felt like I had no blood in my body, literally.
Ali was hoping it was just a robbery.
The men would ransack the house, take jewelry and money, and then leave.
But when they started to look for things to tie her up, she realized that it was going to be much more.
Then they came with my husband's ties, and they tied my hands, my feet.
And they put a pillowcase over my head.
And that's when I knew.
They want to be number one on the list.
They want to know where they are on these various lists.
So, believe me, we get calls about, where are we going to be on the list?
Did we make the list?
But it's more than a single business deal.
Increasingly here, there have been public calls for an end to what's perceived as collusion among Britain's powerful, police and politicians, to protect the interests of a media empire.
Greg Dyke, a former head of the BBC, believes that moment has arrived.
I mean, we've had 30 years, really, where British politics has been influenced and, in some ways, dominated by the Murdoch operation.
And I think that came to an end this week.
And I think that's a profound moment.
But it's unclear to what extent the main players can or will extricate themselves from a tangle of professional loyalties and personal self-interests.
Cameron's former press chief, Andy Coulson, an ex-News of the World editor, was arrested last week in connection with the scandal.
In fact, both Cameron and opposition leader Miliband have hired staffers from the Murdoch stable.
Tomorrow, Cameron will meet face-to-face with some of the alleged hacking targets; the actor Hugh Grant, and the parents of the murdered schoolgirl Milly Dowler.
Cameron said he wants to hear their thoughts about a public inquiry.
For NPR News, I'm Vicki Barker in London.

James Delay is the director of exhibition development for American Exhibitions Incorporated, the company behind ""Mummies of the World."" He says many of the mummies in the exhibit came from one museum in Germany and were once thought to be lost.
He checked their record books and they were listed as canceled right around the time of World War II.
So he assumed that during the ravages and the bombing of Mannheim, that they were either destroyed or given to their, you know, their elite of the museum, the board of directors, if you will.
That must have been an incredible discovery.
Yeah, I mean it was a huge bank vault.
But he did tell me it felt like Christmas Day.
And they came from what part of the world?
They came from South America.
They came from Oceania, Asia, the bogs of Germany.
